# Steps to reproduce
Simple Steps:
```powershell
Remove-Alias "cd"
get-Command "cd" # -> error, remove-alias was successful
cd <ctrl-space> # still shows completions
```
Enhanced Steps:
```powershell
Remove-Alias "cd"
Function Invoke-CdAlternative {
	[cmdletbinding()]
	param(
		[string]$ToPrint
	)
	Write-Host "cdAlternative print argument: $($ToPrint)"
}

Register-ArgumentCompleter -CommandName Invoke-CdAlternative -ParameterName ToPrint -ScriptBlock {
	"foo", "bar" `
	| ForEach-Object { 
		[System.Management.Automation.CompletionResult]::new($_, $_, "ParameterValue", $_)
	}
}

Invoke-CdAlternative <ctrl-space> # successfully extends arguments
new-alias -name "cd" -Value "Invoke-CdAlternative"
cd <ctrl-space> # still shows completions for original cd alias
# on the other hand
new-alias -name "mycdalternative" -Value "Invoke-CdAlternative"
mycdalternative <ctrl-space> # shows the defined completions for invoke-cdalternative
```

# Expected behavior
from Simple Steps
```Powershell
cd <ctrl-space> # shows default completions, all files in current folder?
```

from Enhanced Steps
```powershell
cd <ctrl-space> # shows completions from ArgumentCompleter like the following does:
mycdalternative <ctrl-space>
```

comments.body:
I believe that this is a PSReadline issue, because I hit something similar with a customized cd _function_ I use to replace the cd _alias_.   I wrote about it here 
https://jamesone111.wordpress.com/2019/11/24/redefining-cd-in-powershell/
And in the middle of that there is a statement "PSReadline caches alias parameters and their associated completers"  (and I unload and reload PSReadline to work round this). 

It might be worth raising this with PSReadline folks

(ps. The title may confuse, because an argumentCompleter specifically fills in parameter *values* and this bit of intellisense is something different)

title: Change of alias does not affect argumentcompleter
